creator: jnaveen@ltp.soft.net
text:
Within the <copy> tag, I have used something like this
<filterset>
    <filtersfile file="${env.root}/ttr/src/confReplacement.properties"/>
</filterset>

After I make a change to my properties file, the copy tag should ideally 
re-copy the files with the new filters. This does not happen. This is a useful 
feature.

creator: holtdl@yahoo.com
text:
Couldn't you just use <uptodate> to check the filters file against the copied 
files, in combination with <copy>'s overwrite attribute?  Eg, something like:
<target name="copyfiles">
  <uptodate property="copy.overwrite"
            targetfile="${env.root}/ttr/src/confReplacement.properties">
    <srcfiles dir="${copy.dest.dir}" ... />
  </uptodate>
  <property name="copy.overwrite" value="false"/>
  <copy todir="${copy.dest.dir}" overwrite="${copy.overwrite}">
   ...
  </copy>
</target>

If you agree that's a reasonable solution, please close this bug. Thanks.

I agree that <uptodate> is a good workaround, but I do feel that having <copy> 
use the filter file in its dependency checking is a better solution.
creator: jakarta@ehatchersolutions.com
bodewig@apache.org
text:
But Copy doesn't know that the filterset comes from a file - and I think it is
good that it doesn't know it.

One could use the same argument to say that copy must check the build
file it has been invoked from as well, as you could have changed the value of a
filter defined in it directly.

This is one of the examples <dependset> has been invented for.

Marking as WONTFIX for the reasons given by Stefan. If you require a dependency
on the filterset file, use uptodate and dependset to manage that dependency
explicitly
